DOC.HEAD: Executives Get Prison for Adding Animal Parts to Meat
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Friday sentenced two meat company executives to up to two years in prison for illegally adding animal parts and other substances to meat and ordered $285,000 in restitution. West Meat Co., president Joseph A. West and his son, processing plant manager Jeffrey L. West, pleaded guilty in August to charges of adulterating meat in violation of federal meat laws. U.S. District Judge William Hungate sentenced the elder West to two years in prison and his son to 21 months. The two men and the company were ordered to pay a total of $285,000 in restitution to the state. West Meat, based in the St. Louis suburb Rock Hill, was charged in a federal indictment last June with adding ``unidentified substances previously packaged as pet food,'' to ground beef, pork sausage and Polish sausage. The meats were sold to about two dozen state hospitals, schools and prisons between October 1987 and October 1988, when the scheme was uncovered by federal investigators, the indictment said. The government said that in addition to the pet food substances, beef blood, poultry parts, bones, deer meat, water and extra fat were added to ground beef. Pork sausage was adulterated with several items, including adrenal and salivary glands. Jim Greene, a spokesman for the U.A. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service, said West Meat had voluntarily ceased operations in May. He said the USDA would withdraw inspection services, preventing the company from reopening. Earlier this month, West Meat was banned from doing business with Missouri for 20 years. A state circuit court judge also ordered the company to pay $20,000 to the state and invalidated more than $40,000 in bills owed by Missouri. Greene said the USDA had been involved in about 160 such prosecutions in the last five years. The largest penalty ever assessed a company was $2 million against Sandy Mac Food Co. of Pennsauken, N.J., a ham processing firm that pleaded guilty to bribing federal inspectors, selling adulterated hams and falsifying records. Greene said there are about 7,000 meat slaughtering and processing plants in the United States.
